resources.string: If that all seems like too much effort, I don\'t blame you. The best solution is probably to invest in a password manager (I suspect it\'s what most security professionals do). Click this card to search for one.

When you enter a password into Password123, the first thing the app does is to convert your password into a one-way hash (a one-way hash is random looking text which is difficult to reverse back to the original password - hence "one-way"). Your password is still visible to you on the front page though, so be careful that no one is looking over your shoulder!

 From that point on, the rest of the password checking system is only told about your password hash, not your full password.

 The first check that Password123 does is to look in a list of the 10,000 most common exposed password hashes. This list is stored in the app itself, so it's very quick to check and you can still use this feature even when you have no internet connection on your phone.

 It goes without saying that any password found in that list is extremely insecure and should be changed immediately.

 If Password123 was not able to find your password hash in that list, then so far so good!

 Next it will try to access the internet to check the main haveibeenpwned.com database (that's not a typo, hackers like to use the letter p instead of o, go figure). 

 haveibeenpwned.com is not run by a hacker by the way, it is run by Troy Hunt who is a very well known security professional who works for Microsoft and tours the globe speaking about internet security. The site is continuously updated and exists so that people can check if their personal data has been breached somewhere on the internet. I recommend you take a look at the site, it's illuminating to say the least.

 The haveibeenpwned.com database has hashed passwords from about 5 billion(!) accounts that have been exposed by hackers in the past. You really don't want to have a password which is the same as one on that list. But if you do, the app will let you know immediately so that you can change it.

 So that not even the ihavebeenpwned.com service knows what password hash you are checking, the Password123 app uses the k-anonymity API. Basically this means that only the first few characters of your password hash ever leave your phone, the haveibeenpwned service replies with all the possible matches in it's password hash database (usually a few hundred or so).

 The Password123 app is the only part of the system that knows the full password hash, and it checks for a match among the few hundred results returned to it from the haveibeenpwned service itself. 

 The haveibeenpwned service never knows which of those hundreds of results returned, matched your password - if indeed any of them did.

Password123 is an open source Android app written in Kotlin, the source is available here: https://github.com/erdo/password123 

 The app makes use of these third party libraries and services: 

 haveibeenpwned 
 see: https://haveibeenpwned.com/API/v2#PwnedPasswords 

 OkHttp 
 see: https://github.com/square/okhttp 

 pwned4android 
 see: https://github.com/erdo/pwned4android 

 ASAF 
 see: https://github.com/erdo/asaf-project 

 icons 
 see: https://material.io/icons/
